Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Soft Matter Self-Assembly: Protein Crystallization and Colloidal Microphase Formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award is funded through the Division of Materials Research and the Division of Chemistry. It supports theoretical and computational research and education on soft matter self-assembly. Soft materials are substances whose physical states are easily deformed by thermal-scale energies, and include, among others, liquids, colloids, gels, and a number of biological materials. Though soft matter ordering is a promising approach to assembling complex and interesting materials on the micron and sub-micron scale, a microscopic understanding of even some of the simplest processes involved remains elusive.

The PI will investigate the equilibrium and non-equilibrium behavior of some key contributing microscopic factors to assembly in two families of soft matter systems: proteins and colloidal microphase-formers. This program aims to advance purposeful design strategies for controlling assembly morphology and function.

1) Project on proteins: The PI will research the microscopic contributions to pair protein interactions that control nucleation, in order to suggest novel rational mutagenesis approaches and experimental conditions that facilitate protein crystallization.

2) Project on colloidal microphase-formers: The PI will research the equilibrium and non-equilibrium assembly of microphase patterns in systems of spherical and rod-like particles, in order to understand and control the range of possible morphologies in colloidal assembly.

The educational component supports efforts along two main thrusts:

1) Promoting multidisciplinary learning at the interface of physics, chemistry, and materials science by developing a focus section on soft matter for the general chemistry curriculum, and a materials science concentration for chemistry majors; and

2) Broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in the theoretical sciences by developing an outreach program for high school students in the Durham, NC, community that builds on Duke University's Center for Theoretical and Mathematical Sciences and the Duke-Durham Neighborhood Partnership Program.

NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award is funded through the Division of Materials Research and the Division of Chemistry. It supports theoretical and computational research and education on soft matter. Examples of soft materials can often be found or transformed in a kitchen. Foams, gels, grains, and many biological materials are common examples. Under controlled conditions, soft matter can also form complex and useful structures that have features smaller than a micron, a millionth of a meter. In order to take advantage of these processes for designing new materials and functionalities, a detailed understanding of their assembly at the microscopic level is necessary. The PI will investigate design strategies for controlling the assembly shape, dynamics, and function in two families of soft matter system: proteins and pattern-forming particles.

The educational component supports efforts along two main thrusts:

1) Promoting multidisciplinary learning at the interface of physics, chemistry, and materials science by developing a focus section on soft matter for the general chemistry curriculum, and a materials science concentration for chemistry majors; and

2) Broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in the theoretical sciences by developing an outreach program for high school students in the Durham, NC, community that builds on Duke University's Center for Theoretical and Mathematical Sciences and the Duke-Durham Neighborhood Partnership Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this grant period, the Charbonneau group has used simulations and theory to markedly advance the understanding of soft materials, such as (i) colloidal microphases, (ii) protein crystals, and (iii) amorphous solids. 

(i) Microphases emerge when the short-range attraction between particles is frustrated by longer-range repulsion, whathever the source of attraction and repulsion may be. The morphological richness of the resulting assemblies makes them desirable materials targets, but our relatively crude understanding of these structures prevents controlling their experimental realization.

(ii) Crystals of proteins are essential to obtain their three-dimensional structure through X-rays diffraction. The crystallization of these complex yet essential biomolecules can, however, be remarkably challenging. The fields of structural biology and soft matter have independently sought out principles to understand protein crystal assembly, but have yet to provide consistent guidelines.

(iii) Glasses and other amorphous solids have materials properties that differ markedly from those of crystals. Identifying the origin of these differences, the so-called glass problem, is one of the most challenging theoretical problem in the theory of matter.

Intellectual Merit

(i) A simulation method for solving the phase behavior of model microphase formers has been developed. This advance has identified the equilibrium and out-of-equilibrium assembly properties of microphase-forming materials. Remarkably, even the disordered regime of these systems was found to be highly non-trivial. Reconciling dynamical and equilibrium features of these systems has provided guidelines for accessing these rich materials structures in experiments.

(ii) Using a coarse-grained description of proteins, the phase behavior of model systems has been determined, and validated in experiments. Limits to protein crystal assembly have been identified, which has provided a microscopic understanding of the experimental challenges involved as well as novel guidelines for achieving crystal assembly. In parallel, a big-data study of experimental crystallization results has revealed previously unnoticed trends in protein assembly.

(iii) With the help of a novel approach to numerical simulations, i.e., changing the dimension of space, the most promising theoretical description of glasses has been identified. After carefully testing some of the theoretical predictions, a fundamental flaw in that theory was identified, and quickly fixed. A non-trivial, Garder transition emerged from this re-analysis, and various aspects of that transition were then tested and validated in numerical simulations. This advance, which likely underlies a number of the structural and transport anomalies of amorphous systems, allowed the unification of glass formation in liquid with jamming in packings of grains. Additional limitations of the theory, such as hopping, were also identified, and have stimulated the reexamination of various features of the slowdown that leads to glass formation in supercooled liquids.

Broader Impacts

Four graduate students have benefited from this funding support, and three of them were granted a PhD during the grant duration. The technical and scientific competency of the US workforce was thus enhanced. In addition, a conscious effort was made to help structure the different research communities concerned by the work. For instance, reviews about all three problems have been written. In addition, various workshops on protein assembly and the glass problem as well as a summer school for graduate students and postdoctoral scholars on the physics of disordered systems were organized. A number of public lectures on disordered systems and the soft matter of cooking were given, and popular science articles about the research advances were written. The PI further attended and helped with recruitment at the annual SACNAS conference, in order to encourage broad and inclusive participation of the next generation of American students in STEM research.
